page.title: 15Thame schools 1
page.content: Lord William, a local nobleman, founded the school in 1559 to enable the sons of local farmers and buisnessmen to enter university. School began at 6.00 a.m. and the boys were taught Latin and Religion. Discipline was very strict and the boys were often beaten with canes. Among the scholars were Mr. Speaker Lentall, Bishop Henry, the king of Chichester, Sir George Etherege and the patriot John Hampden. The school declined in the 1860's when visitations by the Warden of New College stopped. In 1874 a new governing body was constituted and the new school opened in 1879. In 1973 the school became a mixed comprehensive joining with the Wenman school at the other end of town and now has the reputation of being one of the biggest (1800 pupils) and best in the country.
